wdpar
  • Reference
  • Articles

Clean data from the World Database on Protected Areas

Clean data from the World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA).

wdpa_clean(x, crs = 3395, tolerance = 1, threads = 1, verbose = FALSE)

Arguments

x

sf object containing data from the WDPA.
crs

character coordinate reference system in PROJ4 format. Defaults to 3395 (Mercator).
tolerance

numeric tolerance for snapping geometry to a grid for resolving invalid geometries.
threads

numeric number of threads to use for processing. Defaults to 1.
verbose

logical should progress on data cleaning be reported? Defaults to FALSE.

Value

sf object.

Details

This function cleans data from World Database on Protected Areas following best practices (Butchart et al. 2015, Runge et al. 2015, https://protectedplanet.net/c/calculating-protected-area-coverage).

  1. Repair invalid geometry (using st_parallel_make_valid).

  2. Exclude protected areas that are not currently implemented (retain areas with the status "Designated", "Inscribed", "Established").

  3. Exclude UNESCO Biosphere Reserves (Coetzer et al. 2014).

  4. Create a field ("GEOMTRY_TYPE") indicating if areas are represented as point localities ("POINT") or as polygons ("POLYGON").

  5. Exclude areas represented as point localities that do not have a reported spatial extent (i.e. missing data for the field

  6. Reproject data to coordinate system specified in argument to crs (using st_parallel_transform).

  7. Repair any invalid geometry that has since manifested (using st_parallel_make_valid).

  8. Buffer areas represented as point localities to circular areas using their reported spatial extent (using data in the field "REP_AREA" and st_buffer).

  9. Assemble land and exclusive economic zone data (using land_and_eez_fetch).

  10. Extract terrestrial protected areas and erase localities that occur in the ocean.

  11. Extract marine protected areas and erase regions that occur on land.

  12. Merge terrestrial and marine protected area data sets.

  13. The "MARINE" field is converted from integer codes to descriptive name (0 = "terrestrial", 1 = "partial", 2 = "marine").

  14. Zeroes in the "STATUS_YR" field are replaced with NA values.

  15. Zoers in the "NO_TK_AREA" field are replaced with NA values for areas for with such data are not reported or applicable (i.e. areas with the values "Not Applicable" or "Not Reported" in the "NO_TK_AREA" field).

  16. Snap geometries to a grid to fix any unresolved geometry issues (using link[lwgeom]{st_snap_to_grid}).

  17. Repair any invalid geometry that has manifested (using st_parallel_make_valid).

  18. Erase overlapping geometries (discussed in Deguignet et al. 2017). Geometries are erased such that protected areas associated with more effective management categories ("IUCN_CAT") or have historical precdence are retained (using st_difference).

  19. Slivers are removed (geometries an area less than 1e-10 square kilometers).

  20. Calculate size of areas in square kilometers (stored in field "AREA_KM2").

References

Butchart SH, Clarke M, Smith RJ, Sykes RE, Scharlemann JP, Harfoot M, ... & Brooks TM (2015) Shortfalls and solutions for meeting national and global conservation area targets. Conservation Letters, 8: 329--337.

Coetzer KL, Witkowski ET, & Erasmus BF (2014) Reviewing Biosphere Reserves globally: Effective conservation action or bureaucratic label? Biological Reviews, 89: 82--104.

Deguignet M, Arnell A, Juffe-Bignoli D, Shi Y, Bingham H, MacSharry B & Kingston N (2017) Measuring the extent of overlaps in protected area designations. PloS One, 12: e0188681.

Runge CA, Watson JEM, Butchart HM, Hanson JO, Possingham HP & Fuller RA (2015) Protected areas and global conservation of migratory birds. Science, 350: 1255--1258.

See also

wdpa_fetch, https://protectedplanet.net/c/calculating-protected-area-coverage.

Examples


# fetch data for the Marshall Islands
mhl_raw_data <- wdpa_fetch("MHL", wait = TRUE)

# clean data
mhl_data <- wdpa_clean(mhl_raw_data)
#> [1] 1
#> Time difference of 0.8077075 secs
#> [1] 2
#> Time difference of 0.1194849 secs
#> [1] 3
#> Time difference of 9.767428 secs
#> [1] 4
#> Time difference of 1.100963 secs
#> [1] 5
#> Time difference of 0.03702474 secs
#> [1] 6
#> Time difference of 13.78201 secs
#> [1] 7
#> Time difference of 0.4758477 secs
#> [1] 8
#> Time difference of 1.781765 secs
#> [1] 9
#> Time difference of 0.0002377033 secs
#> [1] 10
#> Time difference of 2.103779 secs
#> [1] 11
#> Time difference of 0.0004551411 secs
#> [1] 12
#> Time difference of 0.01515126 secs
#> [1] 13
#> Time difference of 0.008233547 secs
#> [1] 14

# plot cleaned data set
plot(mhl_data)
#> Warning: plotting the first 9 out of 28 attributes; use max.plot = 28 to plot all

# plot geometries for visual comparison
par(mfrow = c(1, 2))
plot(sf::st_geometry(mhl_raw_data), main = "orginal data", col = "white")
plot(sf::st_geometry(mhl_data), main = "cleaned data", col = "white")

not_run({
  # fetch data for all protected areas on the planet
  # note that this might take some time given that the global data set is
  # over 1 GB in size
  global_raw_data <- wdpa_fetch("global")

  # set number of threads for processing
  n_threads <- max(1, parallel::detectCores(TRUE) - 1)

  # clean global data set using parallel processing
  global_data <- wdpa_clean(global_raw_data, threads = n_threads)

  # plot data
  plot(global_data)
})
